title: 103_hr40
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commission to Study Reparation Proposals for African Americans Act". The Congress finds that approximately 4,000,000 Africans and their descendants were enslaved in the United States from 1619 to 1865, and that slavery was constitutionally sanctioned from 1789 to 1865. The purpose of this Act is to establish a commission to study the effects of slavery on African Americans and society in the United States. The Act aims to establish a commission to examine slavery from 1619 to 1865, discrimination against freed slaves and their descendants, the lingering effects on African Americans and society, and recommend ways to educate the public on the findings. The Commission will recommend remedies based on its findings and submit the results to Congress. SEC. 3. ESTABLISHMENT AND DUTIES. The Commission to Study Reparation Proposals for African Americans is established to examine the institution of slavery in the United States from 1619 to 1865, including the capture, transport, sale, and acquisition of Africans as chattel property. The Commission to Study Reparation Proposals for African Americans will examine the treatment of African slaves in the colonies and the United States, including the deprivation of their freedom, exploitation of their labor, and destruction of their culture. It will also investigate the extent to which Federal and State governments supported slavery and discriminated against freed African slaves and their descendants after the Civil War. The Commission to Study Reparation Proposals for African Americans will examine discrimination against freed African slaves and their descendants post-Civil War, the lingering effects of slavery on African Americans and society, and recommend ways to educate the public and provide appropriate remedies. The Commission will address whether the US government should apologize for human rights violations against African slaves and their descendants, if African Americans still suffer from the effects of slavery, and if compensation is warranted for descendants of slaves. The Commission will submit a report to Congress with findings and recommendations on compensation for descendants of slaves within one year of its first meeting. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 7 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and President pro tempore of the Senate. Members must have expertise in African American studies. Their term is for life, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The President will convene the first meeting. The President will convene the first meeting of the Commission within 120 days of the Act's enactment or 30 days after appropriations legislation. A quorum consists of four members, who can hold hearings even with fewer present. The Commission will elect a Chair and Vice Chair from its members for the duration of the Commission's existence. Members will receive compensation equivalent to the daily rate of pay for GS-18 for each day of duty. The Commission members will not receive additional pay or benefits for their service. They will be reimbursed for travel and other expenses incurred while performing their duties. The Commission members will not receive additional pay or benefits for their service but will be reimbursed for expenses. SEC. 5 outlines the powers of the Commission. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, request witnesses and documents, and may request the Attorney General's assistance. Subcommittees and members can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can obtain official data from government departments. The Commission can request information from government departments, agencies, and instrumentalities of the executive branch to assist in its duties. Cooperation is required from all entities to provide requested information within the limits of the law. SEC. 6. ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS. The Commission may appoint staff and fix their compensation without following certain civil service laws. The staff can be appointed without regard to competitive service provisions, classification, and pay rate regulations. The compensation of employees cannot exceed the rate for GS-18. The Commission can also hire experts and consultants at specified rates. The Commission can procure supplies, services, and property by contract and enter into agreements with the Administrator of General Services for financial and administrative services. Payment for services will be reimbursed from Commission funds. The Commission can enter contracts with various government agencies, private firms, and institutions for research, surveys, and other necessary activities as provided in appropriations Acts. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report to Congress. $8,000,000 is authorized for carrying out the provisions of this Act.
